page.title: 05Torridon Crofts
page.content: The crofts were good ground,but have not been cultivated for several years.They are rented from{The {National Trust for Scotland}.They run in strips from the road to the sea so that each croft has its share of the good land and access to the shore. The dry stone walls along the road side are still in good condition and have strands of wire on top to keep the red deer out. there is one crofter with sheep; the others do not keep any animals.Most sheep stay on the low ground near the shore, sometimes they are allowed up on the hill, but there is{no common grazing}.Sheep eat seaweed as well as grass and foliage. They are mostly{black face and cheviot with some cross.The lambs and sheep are taken to market at Dingwall,about 60 miles away, or Inverness,80 miles away.Transport(by floats)is expensive.
